content.rendered:
Jonas, the scared teen who is stuck in and out of cycles of the most undervalued concept: time. I have seen your best times and the worst times and everything from the beginning of your story and the end, how quickly you grew up. I refuse to comment on your moral picture, but I may be able to help you with all the glitches in your mind.

I write, not to judge anyone or reveal things prematurely, but to leave a piece of me with you in such testing times. Please follow my requests, and your journey will be smooth. It’s unfair of me to tell you how you’ll be going ahead with a backward push but hold your breath and count to ten and it’ll be 10 more times you’ve missed a chance.

Your dad is dead, and I understand the pain, the dread of not knowing. But everything happens for a reason. Or that every reason needs a task. My words are just brushing the edge of all that there is to know, and of all people, I hate being played with words. So, I’ll give you some hard facts.

You need to be emotionally stable, because 1 mistake and you’ll end up as a villain. You need to let go of your ego because knowledge will be your biggest curse. And above all, refrain from anything that goes against love.

To say you’ll have a happening life is such an understatement, but your childish innocence will handle it all. I see you and I see such a brave man. You inspire me when you take your younger self out to a world that is completely bizarre. You create an example for me when you take up the initiative and start something new. But the most intense thing I was amazed at you for, was to love, through centuries and miles away, and know that it is the only thing that’s true.

 

Love,

Dhruv

Gautam Gandhi

AUTHOR
IT 4th Sem

Ammara Ahmed

DESIGNER

<p><span lang="EN-US">Goodbye! It is such a self-contradictory
word. How is bidding farewell to something or someone even good? Or is it? Why
do we need to say goodbye to the things we are most attached to? For instance,
childhood. Everyone’s favorite phase of life, filled with so much rejoice and
excitement and cute innocence. But then puberty hits, and it might have hit
hard to a few of us, leaving us no choice except to say goodbye. A humongous
list pops out in my mind whenever I think of things that have been an integral
part of my life but had to bid goodbye even for a moment or two if not forever.
Like those crazy, full-of-life days with school friends, insane bike rides in
the town, chess and badminton games with papa, our old house which turned into
a home then, and a very recent one – our hostels and colleges. How can I forget
how much I miss the fights with my sibling too? Oh no, okay, I still do that –
the only constant encountered so far. Just kidding! </span></p>

<p><span lang="EN-US"> </span></p>

<p><span style="color:black" lang="EN-US">Do you remember a time
when you had to say goodbye to someone who has been your ride-or-die person,
your come-hell-or-high water person, your lobster, be it your best friend,
cousin, family member, significant other, or anyone? Goodbyes are goddamn hard
at that point, right? It sounds dreadful that someone who mattered to you more
than your life is no longer with you, either for some time or maybe forever.
Please, don’t kill me for saying this, but what if I say we should be grateful
for this? For what? For having someone with whom you cherished lifelong
memories which will always blossom in your heart. For finding your forever. A
few people have the privilege of meeting their forever type of person, and if
we are one of them, we should be grateful for that. We are so lucky if we have
met someone who makes goodbyes the hardest. If that is something we are not
grateful for, I don’t know for what else we would be? We cannot keep all the
gifts of life. </span><span lang="EN-US">Some things<span style="color:black"> we
are just lent. This reminds me of lines, <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">Muskuraye
toh Muskurane ke karz utaarne honge</i>. The brutal truth is we are the only
guaranteed forever in our life.<span style="mso-spacerun:yes">  </span></span></span></p>

<p><span style="color:black" lang="EN-US"><span style="mso-spacerun:yes"> </span></span></p>

<p><span lang="EN-US">You must be pondering then why the word
includes “good” in it? Sometimes goodbyes can be the gateway to growth. A
courageous leap into the new beginning. There will always be something lying in
front of us that will be much more than what we’ve lost – a person, a memory,
or that lingering bad habit. If we’ll keep re-reading that old chapter – being
the same old us, never trying to upgrade, how will we be able to move to the
next better chapter – better us? So, let us all say goodbye to the normal and
hello to the extraordinary. I guess debate on this word will be never-ending. I
will always have a love-hate relationship with this word. What are your
views?<span style="mso-spacerun:yes">  </span></span></p></div>

content.rendered:
So Mr. Pratik the final arrangements have been made. All thats left is a signature from the new proprietors and the house will be all set to be sold. I must say, its a really pretty house you have. You must be having some really fond memories with it. Said the real estate agent.

Well not really. Its a fact that I lived for 20 years in this house. But now that both mom and dad have passed away its just a liability I would like to be relieved of as soon as possible. It’s not worth holding on to stuff thats no longer useful. Especially an old house with no one to call its own. Replied Pratik with a smirk on his face.

Later that night Pratik went into a deep slumber. He suddenly woke outside the gate of his old house. In front of him, he saw a hooded man staring at the house. Stand up young man. He said as he stared at the house.

Pratik stood up. He looked at the house, it was the same house yet it had an aura of unrest surrounding it. The skies were filled with rumbling thunderclouds with the sound of the grasshoppers following them from every direction. Pratik hesitatingly inquired, Why am I here? What am I doing outside this rusty old house.

Speak less and follow me the sooner we are done here the sooner you will be free. And do not try to walk away from me for if you are lost even I will never be able to find you. Said the hooded man as he opened the gates of the old house. Pratik followed him and the man took him to the hall first.

There he saw a man dressed in a cowboy suit. Ahoy Pratik boy, long time no see. Seeing his face Pratik instantly remembered a TV show he used to watch with his family.

I know you must be confused, but I am only here to take you down the Hall’s memory lane. Remember how you used to watch TV here with your mom and dad.

Then Pratik suddenly had a flashback of how he slept on his moms lap while watching the show and how his dad carried him to the bedroom. Oh, the pleasure it gave me seeing you all together. He said as he covered his tearful eyes with his hat. Pratik had a confused yet sorrowful look in his eyes.

Come with me. The journeys not over. The hooded man said and took him to the kitchen. There a woman in the dress of a waitress was waiting for them.

Oh look how skinny you have become. Seems like you havent been eating good food since you left.. And she continued rambling about his health for the next 10 minutes without catching a breath.

Then she said Oh look at the time. I am sorry. Here have a look at what I wish to show you. She showed him the memory of his birthday and a cake baked by his mother for him with the bliss of innocent happiness on his face.

Your mom and dad may not have earned as much as you have throughout their life, but they surely had a lot of wealth to purchase happiness. Take care of yourself, young man. She said as she placed the palm of her hand on his cheek.

Why are you showing me all this? What is the meaning of all this? he yelled at the hooded man as he sat down grabbing his hair in a state of confusion. You shall receive all the answers at the end of the journey. The hooded man replied calmly.

He then took him to the garden. There he saw an old man who wore a hat and held pruners in his hands looking exactly like a gardener staring at the sky. Seems like my turn has finally come. You know the drill.

The gardener walked up to him, held his hand and showed him a memory of the day he tried the garden swing for the first time and grazed his knee. During your first time, you increased the speed of the swing so much that you lost your balance at a height and fell. You cried a lot that day kid but so did I. he sighed and continued staring at the clouds.

So whos next? Pratik inquired in a gloomy tone as his conscious began to prick him as he tried holding his tears back. We are close to the end. Replied the man.

They then went to his bedroom. There they saw a man who looked exactly like his favourite action figure. Welcome to the final room kid. Remember me, the red ranger. Your favourite hero. You always hanged my poster on your wall.”

He then looked into his eyes and showed him the final memory. The final part was filled with glimpses that brought tears to his eyes. I have witnessed it all kid. Your heartbreaks, your sickness, your lonesome tears, your struggle everything. I have seen the version of you the world will never witness. Look at those thunderclouds!

He pointed towards the window. Even though the sky is covered by those dark clouds it doesnt mean the stars arent there. And we have a lot of faith in our star. He added as he looked at the hooded man with a smile. The man turned his face away from him.

But. Just as he was about to say something he was suddenly teleported outside his house again and was surrounded by those four people again.

Wait a minute, what is all this? This is all too hard for me to process. Were you guys alive the entire time? And more importantly what are you? Please, someone, tell me something. He wailed with tears dripping from his eyes as his words were eaten by his overflowing emotions.

We are the spirits kid. The very manifestation of the emotions that your parents filled this house with. Said the cowboy. You were about to leave us and that made us really sad. Said the maid. Of course we knew this day would surely come. added the gardener. But all we wanted was for you to leave with happy memories and not discontent towards us. We all wish for your progress. But in return, all we demand is a proper farewell. Said the superhero.

I am sorry. I am sorry for everything I said. For ever mistreating you. And thank you so much for staying by my side all these years. Said Pratik with his hands joined and tears flowing down his eyes.

I understand them all but, who are you hooded guy? he asked. I am the very creator of this house Pratty and frankly I am proud of the way you have grown. Its time for you to return. Goodbye. Dont forget I am always watching your back He said in a different yet warm and familiar voice.

Pratty, there is only one man in this world who called me that. He exclaimed. Suddenly the ground beneath him opened up and he fell down into the darkness. He yelled Daaaadd.. as he fell down.

When he finally woke up, he was perspiring as if he had run a 400 m race. Then he realized that whatever happened, it all occurred in his dream. He started crying again and went back to the house.

There he spent an hour in every room reliving his past. And finally, before selling the house he refurbished every room as if it were his own. In the end, he bid a final farewell to his old home with all the respect and love it deserved.

Mufaddal Suratwala

content.rendered:
Far from the central doab lied one of the largest valleys of Asia, the Sutkan valley. Sutkan Valley was one of the least travelled places due to its dangerous roads and the cursed town of Sutkan Valley which was feared even by the bravest of men. Nayannagar, the cursed town which lied in the middle of Sutkan Valley got its moniker after it was cursed by the God of Light. Kirtan was walking alone through this valley after a storm took him away from his crew members. He was afraid but the fact that he was going towards a cursed town intrigued him a lot. Though he was a scholar in various fields and a courtier of Kumbhal State, he was always ready to learn more. After getting rejected by quite a few merchants who were travelling through the same route, he decided to enter the cursed town to find a coachman who could take him to his house. He was astonished after seeing the marvelous fortress which lied in front of his eyes. As he entered the first thing which he saw was a huge rectangular stone on which words inscribed deeply. All this was carved on the board with golden colour making it more enormous and important. The statements inscribed on it were

” WE ARE GRATEFUL FOR THE KAMANAS.” ” 50 MORE YEARS TO COMPLETE OUR CURSE”

” WE ARE SORRY FOR OUR PAST MISTAKES, WE ARE BLESSED TO HAVE THE KAMANAS AS OUR RULING CLAN”

” THE MORE WE SERVE, THE MORE WE SEE”

Kirtan was shivering after reading the statements mentioned on the board. He knew the story about this town was not ridiculous. He knew something was wrong with this town. At the first sight nothing appeared strange about the place, like every other town there were small huts made from bricks and stones, farmers coming from their daily work, small children playing with sheep and goats. But the curse made all the difference. A long time ago, when Nayannagar was flourishing in trading with the nearby states and was bringing a lot of wealth to their King. One of the natives tried to enter in the citadel (a place where the kamanas used to stay) and stole gold coins from them. At that time Lentiqua ( God of Light) came and cursed the people of Nayannagar that you all will live in darkness and whoever will see the light of day or night would suffer pain which would be intolerable. “Wear a black patch around your eyes, live in darkness, your coming generation will also remain curse and this will go on for 100years.”

Kirtan remembered how people were afraid of Lentiqua in his state too. Even the kings with much bigger army use to think twice before doing anything against the ruling king of Nayannagar.

What surprised Kirtan was the ability of people to work in harmony even though their eyes were covered with a black patch. He saw a person riding a bullock cart with so much ease and comfort. He was dumbstruck by seeing the capability of the villagers to work without having the power to see anything. As soon as he went in the main market of the Village, he saw board praising the KAMANAS in various ways

Our ancestral curse could be withdrawn if we will serve the people of citadel relentlessly.

Their eyes are our eyes.

If I will try to remove my patch, the curse will still affect my children.

These statements were inscribed in a braille writing method so that the blind could read it. Everyone had to read it as a part of their daily routine. Kirtan was already in awe with the weirdness of this town.

As he was tired and there was no cartman which could take him to his state. He decides to stay in Nayanngar for the rest of the day. After having his dinner he was roaming near the market when a man started acting as if he was going through a lot of pain. He was running here and there, throwing things which were around him and mumbling something which no one was able to understand properly.

“I just don’t understand what is wrong with the youth, they think they are very smart. See what happens when you test your smartness against God.”

“He tried to remove his black patch! That’s why Lentiqua punished his soul!”

Unable to understand the situation, everyone was giving their opinions based on what they think the situation was but due to the fear of Lentiqua, everyone was terrified.

There was fear, anger and a lot of ignorance.

In a few minutes, The kamanas came with their guards and took the man inside their citadel to treat him even though there was no treatment, just some ailments which could reduce the pain before the body gives up. Kirtan was terrified after seeing this, till now he didn’t believe in Lentiqua completely but after seeing what happened in front of his eyes, he was sure that the legend of Lentiqua is not a fad but a real freaking thing. He went asleep after all the ruckus ended. After having a good sleep, he woke up at 4:00am so that he could start his journey as soon as possible.

As no cartman were available that early, he started searching for some help near the citadel (a place where the kamanas lived). He was about to pull the gate when he heard a familiar voice coming from a house inside the citadel. Unable to recall whose voice was it, he tries to be as close to the house as possible so that he could listen properly to what they are talking. Indeed it was the same man who was possessed by Lentiqua yesterday.

“They are fools!”

“Yes, You are right and the credit goes to our King who used an unreal nonexistent legend to manipulate the people so that they work for us without asking any questions.”

“Exactly and we just have to enact this act of getting possessed by Lentiqua. So that no one ever tries to remove the black patch. Fear could drive people crazy.”

Kirtan was still not able to believe what he just heard, what should he believe now?

The ugly truth which questions the purity of humans and how far they could go to fulfil their desires or The beautiful fictional story of Lentiqua which made life a living hell for the villagers. A lie which forever implanted fear and ignorance in their minds. A lie which made them slaves both physically and mentally. He decided that he will bring the truth to their lives, he will bring the light in their life once again. He was about to run from the citadel so that he could tell the truth when a native Kamana saw him and stabbed him to death. “He was being possessed by Lentiqua last night and due to his intolerable act of vandalising our property and his failed attempt to steal from us, he was being killed last night.” This is how the news was communicated to the villagers. For them

he was just another crazy man who tried to outsmart the God of Light, Lentiqua…

Don’t let your belief to overshadow what is true and real.

If you are not manipulating the society then you are getting manipulated by the society

Pruthviraj Gohil

AUTHOR
IT 4th Sem

Ammara Ahmed

DESIGNER
MBBS 2nd year

I have been watching many movies recently because of staying at home! Before a month or two I watched a movie named ‘Jhalki’ which was based on the story of an elder sister and his little kid brother who was dragged into the world of bonded labor. In that movie, I came to know about you, Boman Irani sir played your role in the movie. It inspired me a lot and I started searching for more about your deeds!

I found it quite amusing that I was ignorant of a personality like you. Gradually I came to know that you campaigned against child labor in India and advocated the universal right to education! In 2014 you were the co-recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize along with Malala Yousafzai for your struggle against the suppression of children and young people and the right of all children to education.

In one of your interviews, I came to know that your exceptionally idealistic and helpful nature was inculcated by your mother. It was very disheartening to hear that you had such a tough childhood. You were significantly affected by the lack of school access for all children. Even though you managed to become a lecturer in your early days. Your experiences of poverty in your childhood made you a fine man which is now admired by everyone around you.

You gave up your career as an electrical engineer and then founded the ‘Bachpan Bachao Andolan’ (Save Childhood Movement), conceived and led the Global March against Child Labour and its International advocacy body, the International Center on Child Labor and Education (ICCLE). When I noticed your exquisite works, somewhere in my heart I felt like I should also do something for society. Your ‘Bachpan Bachao Andolan’ and GoodWeave International captured my attention to a great extent! In one of your interviews, you told that the movement identifies, liberates, rehabilitates, and educates the victims of child labor, trafficking, ethical trade, and much more. Many child-friendly villages are your creations. Your GoodWeave International is very much active in the eradication of child labor in the rug-making industry.

You said that you remember your mother and father the most. Your mother saw you being attacked. Just like every mother she also cried when you left your engineering for this cause. But still, your parents encouraged you! In one of your interviews, you told that the victims of child abuse told you that they weren’t kids anymore because of the events that happened to them which were unforgivable. Although you helped them out of their trauma so nicely. You addressed everyone that we all should befriend the children. No one should see them as pitiable subjects. People often relate childish behavior to stupidity or foolishness. This attitude needs to be changed!

I am looking forward to reading your books! Will for Children, Because Words Matter, Every Child Matters, and The light of the Same Sun are your masterpieces of literature! You not only inspire me from books but also from your quotes. “The single aim of my life is that every child is:

free to be a child,

free to grow and develop,

free to eat, sleep, see daylight,

free to laugh and cry,

free to play,

free to learn, free to go to school, and above all, free to dream.”

Your this way of thinking compelled me to write you an open letter. In the end, I would like to pass on the message which you preached, we should never ignore or let go of the malpractices of child abuse or child labor within our sight and should take a stand for anything happening around us.

Gautam Gandhi

AUTHOR
IT 3rd Sem

Meet Mehta

Nothing ever dies an ultimate death in middle-class families. Probably the toothpaste hack is the most famous one wherein toothpaste is dissected and used until the inner surface shines vibrantly. Indian mothers are known for recycling things. You never know that the Holi colors once you used could be used again on Diwali. Every single thing is saved from being disposed of by saying “It might be helpful soon”.

Once upon a time disciple of Buddha asked for a new robe. Buddha questioned that what you did with the old robe. Disciple answered, “I made a curtain out of it”.  What about the old curtain? Buddha asked. “Oh, that I converted into a bedsheet”. And the old bed sheet? “I made mop out of it”. And the mop? “Dear Lord mops was in the stranded form so I made wicks out of it and I light it up every evening”. Buddha smiled upon the enlightenment of his disciple. That disciple is none other than an Indian Mother. When kanjoosi went abroad for studying it returned as sustainability. What was considered cheap then is now cool! Recycling is seen everywhere and at every step. The newspaper becomes book covers and glossy magazines are turned into a cone for eating mouth-watering bhel. If jeans were torn off then they get a makeover as shorts. However, now Ripped jeans are a style statement.

Every middle-class kid would have felt embarrassed because of the thrifty ways of their mom. It’s just that after we started using phones we came to know that those DIY videos were inspired by our household’s methods. Being frugal is considered cool but without economic restrictions. They might have been raised under tough economic situations so they value money and things bought. Throwing away things is just not their cup of tea. “It cannot be thrown so it must be reused!” It’s their perfect ideology for sustainability.

Try entering the kitchen and their mindful hacks will blow your mind! Leftover rice gets refurbished into mouthwatering cutlets. Pav bhaji was originally a mesh of leftover veggies. This art of recycling and reusing is every environmentalist’s dream. Save- the-planet folks must appoint Indian Mom as president. It’s no longer being a miser but it’s all about being #woken_up.

 

 

 

Muskan Vora

EC 4th Sem

In these unprecedented and changing times, two alumni of Dharmsinh Desai university have devoted themselves to assist people in need, in an effort to fight hunger and help families adversely affected by the pandemic.

Dr. Sajid Mogal (2015) and Dr. Furqan Maulvi (2016) are alumni of DDU, who were guided for their Ph.D. thesis by Dr. Dinesh O. Shah – founder of Shah-Schulman Center for Surface Science and Nanotechnology, DDU. After Ph.D., Dr. Mogal took a teaching position in Central Gujarat near Mehsana and  Dr. Maulvi rejoined as a faculty member at Maliba Pharmacy College, Surat. When the Covid-19 hit their areas, both of them devoted their spare time to assist the people undergoing tragedies. 

The other student, Dr. Sajid Mogal provided leadership to offer a medical treatment Center for Covid-19 victims by collecting donations amounting up to 2.5 crore rupees, rent a large hall, provide 30 beds, hire medical staff and obtain Oxygen cylinders for patients. The government approved charge is Rs. 17,000 per day per bed for Covid-19 patients in government hospital and much larger in private hospitals, which is about 75,000 rupees per day per patient.  In this hall, the charges for the treatment are just Rs. 1.0 per day.  This hall serves as a blessing to poor people and those who could not get into regular hospitals.

The students of Gujarati medium were facing problem during pandemic as the online courses were having quality lecture notes in Gujarati. Dr Mogal who had schooling in Gujarati medium   took initiative and started YouTube channel “Space and Time” for Physics (JEE/NEET content) in Gujarati. More than 700 students across Gujarat attend this high quality courses free (https://www.youtube.com/c/SajidMogal)

Dr. Furqan Maulvi organized Faiza-ne-Panjetan Committee to distribute free food, milk, fruits and vegetables to 450 victim families in Surat for 3 months.  The Committee was awarded by SMC and Surat Jain Samaj. Dr. Dinesh Shah was deeply touched by their social service that he sent his own contribution (1000 USD) to assist in their food distribution program.

The help was given to all victims irrespective of their religion. Dr. Mogal and Dr. Maulavi are doing commendable work and continue to aid people in need on top of their regular duties in their colleges. 

Whenever times get tough, people emerge as heroes to help in any way possible and serve as inspiration for others. What India needs is a new generation of young people like these two students to provide leadership and inspire people to go above and beyond. India can move forward rapidly if all of us unite as equals, help each other and fight for humanity.

23મી સદી,

16 JAN, 2299

સમાચાર પત્રની પ્રથમ હરોળ:

સેલ લેબ્સ દ્વારા જનીનમાં રહેલી માહિતીને કમ્પ્યુટર પ્રોગ્રામમાં રૂપાંતર કરવામાં વૈજ્ઞાનિકોને સફળતા મળી છે . મનુષ્યજાતિ હવે નિરોગી જીવનની ખૂબ નિકટ છે.

જનીન પ્રયોગશાળામાં ઉપસ્થિત વૈજ્ઞાનિકો ત્રાકકણોને અતિ શક્તિશાળી બનાવવાનો વિચાર વિમર્શ ચાલી રહ્યો છે કારણકે, મનુષ્યના ત્રાકકણ રોગ પ્રતિકારક શક્તિ માટે જવાબદાર છે! આ અભ્યાસ 4 વર્ષ સુધી ચાલ્યો અને જનીનની માહિતી પરથી માનવનિર્મિત રસાયણો બનાવાયા અને પરિક્ષણ શરુ કરાયું. થોડા દિવ્યાંગ લોકોની પરવાનગી લઇ તેના પર પરીક્ષણ કરતા સાબિત થયુ કે વર્તમાન રસાયણ મનુષ્યના ચેતાતંત્રને ખૂબ નુકસાન પહોંચાડે છે. હવે પ્રયોગ ફક્ત ચેતાતંત્રને નુકસાન ન પહોંચે તેના માટે ચાલ્યો અને અંતમાં એક શરત ઉદ્ભવી કે, 10ms ના સમયગાળામાં નવા જન્મેલા ત્રાકકણને જો રસાયણમાં ઉમેરવામાં આવે તો પ્રયોગ સફળ થાય.

અથાગ પ્રયત્નો કરવા છતા યંત્રો દ્વારા આ કામ પાર ન પાડી શકાયું કારણકે, 10ms ના અંતરમાં ત્રાકકણોની અસરકારકતા ધરખમ રીતે બદલાઈ રહી હતી. જો મનુષ્ય આ કાર્ય પાર પાડે તો કંઇક નવો ઉદ્ભવ થઈ શકે . જનીનીક માહિતીને કમ્પ્યુટર કોડમાં રૂપાંતર કરી તેમાં જરૂરી ફેરફાર કરીને એક એવા જનીનનું નિર્માણ કરાયું કે જે મનુષ્ય તે જનીન ધારણ કરશે તેની 10ms એ સામાન્ય મનુષ્યન 1s થશે. વૈજ્ઞાનિક પ્રક્રિયા દ્વારા બે મહિનાના એક અનાથ બાળક પર નવનિર્મિત જનીન લાગુ પાડવામાં આવ્યુ.આ પ્રયોગમાં 1 વર્ષ જેટલો સમય પસાર થયો. પરીક્ષણના અંતે જન્મ થયો હાઇબ્રીડ જનીન યુક્ત મનુષ્યનો!

પરિક્ષણ બાદ ત્વરિત તેના પર પ્રયોગો શરુ થયાં. તેને ઇજા પહોંચાડી અને તેની શારીરિક ક્ષમતા માપવાના પ્રયાસો કરવામાં આવ્યા. ફક્ત એક દિવસમાં તે બાળક ભાષાનો અભ્યાસ કરે છે અને જયારે બોલતા શીખે છે ત્યારે પૂછે છે, મને પીડા કેમ થાય છે? વૈજ્ઞાનિકો પરિક્ષણમાં વ્યાકુળ હોઈ છે અને ઉત્તર કંઈક આવો આવે છે “આ પીડા અમે નહિ તારા શરીરની અંદર ઉદ્દભવી રહેલું લેક્ટિક એસિડ તને પીડા આપે છે!” અને પરીક્ષણ પુનઃ શરૂ કરે છે. તે બાળકને આ સાંભળ્યા બાદ આશ્ચર્ય થાય છે! તે આ બાબતમાં જ્ઞાન પ્રાપ્ત કરવાનું વિચારે છે. બાળક તેની જ્ઞાનની ક્ષુધા સંતોષવા માટે એક માસની અંદર ડોક્ટરની પદવી પ્રાપ્ત કરે છે.તે સ્વયં પણ નિરોગી જીવનના રસાયણનું સંશોધન શરૂ કરે છે. તે બાળક સંશોધનના અંતે વૈજ્ઞાનિકોને કહે છે કે ઠીક 4 માસ બાદ આ પ્રયોગ પૂર્ણ થશે. પ્રયોગ પૂરો કરવાની એટલી નજીક હોવા છતાં 4 માસ સાંભળી અને વૈજ્ઞાનિકો પાગલ થઇ છે અને તેને ઈજા પોહોચાડવાનો પ્રયત્ન કરે છે. વૈજ્ઞાનિકો પૈકી એક વૈજ્ઞાનિકે મનુષ્યના રંગસૂત્રોના આભ્યાસ પરથી તારણ કાઢેલ હોઈ છે કે મનુષ્યના રંગસૂત્રોમાં બદલાવ ભાગ્યે એક લાખ માંથી એક વાર સફળ જાય છે અને તેમની પાસે હવે એટલો સમય નથી કે તે બીજા પર પરિક્ષણ કરે એટલે તે બાળકને જ પરિક્ષણનો ભાગ બનાવવો પડશે અને પછી તેને ઇજા દેવાનું બંધ કરે છે.

24મી સદી,

19 FEB,2306

પરીક્ષણનું સેટઅપ તૈયાર છે, પ્રાપ્ત કરેલું રસાયણ પણ ઉત્તમ કક્ષાનું બની ચૂક્યું છે, છ વર્ષનું વૃદ્ધ ત્રાકકણો ઉમેરવા માટે તત્પર છે અને પરીક્ષણ શરૂ થાય છે. જ્યારે ત્રાકકણનો કોષ રસાયણ પર પડે છે તુરંત જ પ્રયોગશાળા વિસ્ફોટ સાથે નષ્ટ થઇ જાય છે. ફક્ત એક વૈજ્ઞાનિક જીવતો રહે છે અને તેને સખત ઈજા પહોંચે છે. તે કારણ શોધવાનો પ્રયત્ન કરે છે અને તેના હાથમાં છ વર્ષના વૃદ્ધનો પત્ર હાથ લાગે છે. પત્રમાં કંઈક આવું લખેલું હોય છે…

“આ પીડા હું નહિ તારા શરીરની અંદર ઉદ્દભવી રહેલું લેક્ટિક એસિડ તને પીડા આપે છે! મનુષ્ય જાતિની વાસ્તવિકતાનો જો વિચાર કરવામાં આવે ત્રાકકણોની સાંદ્રતા વધી જવાથી મનુષ્યના રક્તકણો નાશ પામે છે અને મનુષ્યનું જીવન ટૂંકાવે છે નીરોગી જીવન જીવવું એક સપનું છે પરંતુ પ્રકૃતિના નિયમો સાથે છળ એ વાસ્તવિકતા નથી. મારું મૃત્યુ પ્રયોગશાળાના પ્રયોગના કારણે નહીં પરંતુ મારી હાલ 50 વર્ષની ઉંમરના કારણે થયું છે. મૃત્યુ બાદ રસાયણમાં ભળેલો ત્રાકકણ રસાયણિક પ્રક્રિયાથી વિસ્ફોટ સર્જે છે પરંતુ હવે આ બાબત વિશે ચર્ચા કરવી મિથ્યા છે.આપણે કોઈ પણ પ્રયોગોના તમામ પાસાનો આભ્યાસ કરવો જોઈએ અને મનુષ્યએ કોઈ દિવસ પ્રકૃતિએ નશ્ચિત કરેલી હદની ઉપરવટ ન જવું જોઈએ. નમસ્તે!”

સમાચાર પત્રની પ્રથમ હરોળ:

સેલ લેબ્સમાં 5 વૈજ્ઞાનિક અને 6 મહિનાના વૃદ્ધનું મૃત્યુ! 6 મહિનાના વૃદ્ધની સાચી ઉંમર 50 વર્ષ હોવાનું જાહેર થયું છે!તે સામાન્ય મનુષ્ય કરતા 100 ગણા ઝડપી હતા!

Kashyap Joshi

content.rendered:
We have all had our own share of being forced to listen to old music. It remains a different vibe in itself; car rides with family, middle aged people “jamming (¿) hard” to old bollywood songs while the children think “agli baar se aage baithenge”. In the midst of these trips, somewhere far and few I came across classical pieces like Jhanak Jhanak Baje Payaliya, not to mention the more recent adaptations like Albela Sajan. The grandeur reminds me of weddings and how over-the-top they can be!

Apart from these, because of YouTube and Spotify, I came across completely stunning semi-classical like Mora Saiyan, and I connected best with other sufi compositions like Chhap Tilak. These compositions beautifully inculcate romanticism and spirituality and I love them because that’s all they want, to be loved and to spread love.

Because of a friend, I came across Begum Akhtar and her mesmerising thumris, like Ab Ke Saavan Ghar Aana and Tum Jao Mose Na Bolo. The former takes me down the nostalgic lane and reminds me of home, and somehow also ends up making me question what the word home really means to me. Some of the lyrics are so ingenious, they really make you wonder, like the lines of Balamwa Tum Kya Jaano Preet. This screams a very obvious yet ignored reality that in life and love, there can never be a perfect reciprocation.

Having grown up in the Chaturvedi community, I was also very familiar with another folk style of classical music: Horis. For this, I could give numerous examples, from the most popular Dhap Bajo Ri to Chanda Jaiyo Re Kahiyo, these are mostly devotional in nature. I had also found a CD that I got from Crossword a long time ago but never bothered to listen; Pads by Surdas. The one that stood our for me was Re Man Murakh Janam Ganvayo. I love this one particularly because it portrays the apprehensive nature of our lives, the thing I might love right now may not be in future and my future may be worlds apart, and you can never know.

I was introduced to Ghazals and the singer was Dr. Radhika Chopra, and the way she has mastered the art of singing left me pleasantly surprised. Some of her best included Aapki Yaad Aati Rahi and Mujhse Pehli Si Mohobbat. The latter was originally sung by Mallika-e-Tarannum, Noor Jahan, and it is an evergreen masterpiece, because the hope even in grieving always stays alive.

When one dives in the deep ocean of classical music, they will realize that even though today’s music is easier to groove to, there is a specific charm that lies in old tracks. Call it nostalgia, or just a very meticulous structured art, one cannot get enough of it. From the pop sensations of Bollywood to melodious symphonies from the West, music as an art will forever bind everyone, and the deep roots of it; classical music, will protect it from everything.

Dhruv Pathak

AUTHOR
MBBS 2nd Year

Vishesh Waghela

content.rendered:
I sometimes wonder, why are “mountains or beaches” even a question? It is and forever will be mountains. Sorry, Thallosophiles. And what can be more ecstatic for an Acrophile than being brought up in a town surrounded by mountains? Yes, I’m that lucky person who had a wonderful childhood in the towns of beautiful Holy Girnar. But now after shifting to another metropolis, I miss watching this beauty in complete awe from my window, terrace, car, etc. I would stare at it whenever I got a chance, just for a glance. You see, I can rhyme. I recently went on a hike to Girnar with my friends. It was an extraordinary experience but fun fact your legs might pain up to a week.

We, as humans, always crave for deep connection. Be it with nature, people, or anything. Nothing else can fill the void as mountains do, by holistically healing my mind, body, and soul. It just tranquilizes my mind and makes me more serene. Just imagining a breath-taking vista of the valley loaded with trees and flowers, small streams passing by, chirping of the birds, orange sunset, fresh life-enhancing clean air makes me more mindful. Only thinking makes me serene yet lively, what would experience do! Next time you go hiking I would encourage you to do a few things. I am sure you’d go for a hike now because I’m instructing you to go. JUST GO MAN and while wandering stop and stare at the beauty around. Just stare, immerse into its beauty and relax like there’s nothing to do. No work, no exams, no assignments, nothing. You can also journal on top of the world and listen to the silence. For me, taking heed to the silence is the most underrated skill. Once you start enjoying solitude, there’s no going back.

I’ve been to quite a few mountains, but you’ll find a unique amalgamation of three forms of water in the mountains of North. Snow here, liquid water there, fog everywhere. Rhyme count++. But true adrenaline rush comes only when you’re on a jeep hurrying on bend roads which are hugging the mountains on one side and there’s a deep valley on the other. Of course, there is so much more apart from its beauty. It has added so many new perspectives to my life. For instance, to achieve a deep sense of meaningfulness and success you would have to take the stairs and sweat it out.

No matter how much I praise it, no picture or words would justice to it other than experiencing it for real. As a matter of fact, we love going against, right? So, why not go against gravity. Pack your bags, escape from the chaos, and be ready to see the world from the top. One last thing, the world is astounding, and so are you!

Sing along with me,

Give me some sunshine,

Give me some rain,

Give me another chance,

To go on treks again!

Janki Vaghasiya

title.rendered: શું હું એક લેખિકા બની શકું?

content.rendered:
પડોશમાં રહેતી મારી મિત્ર એક નૃત્યકાર છે અને તે નૃત્ય સાથે ખૂબ લગાવ ઘરાવે છે. તેણે નૃત્યને જાણે જીવનમાં વણી જ લીધું હોય.આ વાત તો સહજ છે કે નૃત્યકારને નૃત્ય સાથે લગાવ હોય જ છે. તેવી જ રીતે એક ક્રિકેટરને ક્રિકેટ સાથે ખૂબ લગાવ હોય છે. પરંતુ શું એક લેખકને પુસ્તક સાથે લગાવ હોવો જરૂરી જ છે? હું પુસ્તકો વાંચવામાં વધુ રસ નથી ધરાવતી. પરંતુ મને કંઈક નવું–નવું લખવાનો ખૂબ શોખ છે. પુસ્તક વાંચીને જ લેખક બની શકાય એ જરૂરી નથી. જો મનના વિચારો પાના ઉપર છાપી શકાય તેવા હોય તો કદાચ પુસ્તક વાંચનાર નહીં, પુસ્તક લખનાર બની શકાય.

કામ વગર બેઠેલો માણસ જો નકામો જ ગણાતો હોય, તો મારામાં અને તે માણસમાં કોઈ જ ફર્ક નથી. કારણકે હું મારા વ્યર્થ જતા સમયમાં પણ પુસ્તકનો આશરો નથી લેતી. પરંતુ હાથ પગનો ઉપયોગ કર્યા વગર માત્ર મનથી કામ લેવું શું યોગ્ય નથી? હું મારા વિચારોથી બંધાયેલી છું. રાત્રે સૂવાના સમય પછી એક પળનો પણ સમય એવો નથી હોતો, જેમાં મારુ મન કોઈ વિચારણા નહીં કરતું હોય. સાંજના સમયે બહાર ઝૂલા ઉપર એકાંતમાં બેઠેલા સામાન્ય વ્યક્તિની સામે એક ફળથી ભરેલું વૃક્ષ ઉભું હોય અને તે વ્યક્તિ આ વૃક્ષને નિહાળે, તો તે માણસ શું વિચારશે? એ જ કે ‘લીલા–પીળા પાંદળાઓ વચ્ચે આ લાલ ફળ કંઈક અલગ જ તરી આવે છે‘. પરંતુ હું આ વિચારથી આગળ વધી કંઈક આવા વિચારમાં ઘુસી જઈશ કે,

“વખાણી રંગત ફૂલોની ,કોઈ ઋણ ના જુએ થડનું;

કહે વૃક્ષ મનને, સમય શીખવે મૂલ બધાયનું;

પાનખર આવે ને આવે નસીબે અંધેર;

શોભા રહે ના રહે, થંભો રહે મારે ઘેર.”

આમ પુસ્તકોથી અજાણ એવી હું રાત– દિવસ મારા જ વિચારોમાં ગૂંથાયેલી રહું છું . હું કોઈ લેખિકા તો નથી પરંતુ મનમાં ચાલતા વિચારો, આંખો સામે આવતા દ્રશ્યો, અને મારી અટપટી પંક્તિની રચનાઓ અદ્રશ્ય કાગળ પર અંકિત કરતી રહું છું. આ કાગળ ની પહોળાઈ ભલે ને ૧૨ ઇંચ હોય, પરંતુ લંબાઈ કંઇક વધારે જ. કારણકે મારી સહનશક્તિની એક સીમા છે, મારી કામ કરવાની ક્ષમતાની પણ એક સીમા છે, પરંતુ મારી વિચારશક્તિની કોઈ સીમા નથી. હું ભલે પુસ્તકો સાથે જોડાયેલી નથી પણ મારા વિચારોને કાગળ પર સહજ ભાવે પ્રદર્શિત કરી શકું છું. મહાપુરુષો ઉપર ઘણી બધી પુસ્તકો લખાયેલી છે. જેમકે, ‘ગાંધીજીની આત્મકથા‘ , ‘સરદાર પટેલ: લોખંડી પુરુષ‘. કહેવાય છે કે જેણે પોતાના વિચારોને આદર્શ રાખીને પોતે જીવી બતાવ્યું છે તેમનું નામ દરેકના સ્મૃતિપટથી ભૂસાતું નથી. દિગ્ગજ લેખકો પણ તેમના ચરિત્ર ને કંડારવા આતુર હોય છે. આવા પુસ્તકો ની રચનામાં કદાચ મને એક શીર્ષક બનવા મળે તો હું મારું અહોભાગ્ય ગણીશ. એક વાતની મને ખાતરી છે કે હું પોતાનું વર્ણન સરસ રીતે કરી શકું છું. તો શું હું મારા નામને જ મારી પુસ્તકનું શીર્ષક બનાવી શકું?

 

કહેવાય છે કે પુસ્તકો જીવનને અનુલક્ષી ઘણું બધું શીખવે છે. તો હું એક પુસ્તક બનવા માંગુ છું. જેમાં હાથ–પગથી ચાલતી દુનિયાથી બહાર આ લેણદેણની ગણતરી, પ્રકૃતિના સંદેશ, અને ‘વિના હદે ચાલતી મનની કામગીરી:વિચારણા‘, આ બધું જ વર્ણન થયું હશે. તો શું હું એક પુસ્તક બની શકું? નકામા મગજમાં છપાયેલ પુસ્તક, જો કોઈકને કામ આવી શકે, તો શું હું આ પુસ્તકની લેખિકા બની શકું?

Sakshi Patel

AUTHOR
IT 3rd Sem

Gaurav Jha

DESIGNER
MH 5th Sem

Sakshi Patel

IT 3rd Sem

content.rendered:
Everyone admires and respects you as a chairperson of the Infosys foundation, but I didn’t know you till I saw you as a celebrity guest in a “Karmaveer” episode of Kaun Banega Crorepati(KBC). I guess I got a lot more motivated when I watched that one.

You are an extraordinary assortment of skills that left me amused when I first saw your interviews. I would rather say that are beyond amazing. You are an engineering teacher, Kannada, Marathi, and English author as well as a social worker. I wonder how could you manage to serve so many rules despite so many responsibilities. Maybe you are superhuman!

Your story always inspired me and kept me motivated. I would like to read your books How I taught my Grandmother to Read, Wise and Otherwise, and three thousand stitches! The description of The three thousand stitches left me with a great impact.

You have always been a star student from your childhood until you completed your graduation! I remember one of the stories of your post-graduation from the Indian Institute of Science Bangalore. The principal asked you to wear a saree as well as he demanded from you that you should not talk with any boy in the college premises. Of course, you fulfilled the demands but after achieving first place among six hundred students, the classmates started approaching you, and you had become the center of attention. I must say you have turned the tables very well.

You became the first female engineer hired as India’s largest auto manufacturer TATA Engineering and Locomotive Company (TELCO). I appreciate your courage about writing a postcard to the company’s chairman complaining about the “man only” gender bias at TELCO. As a result, you were granted a special interview and because of your skills, you were hired immediately. I cannot count how many awards and appreciation you have earned! You even won India’s fourth highest civilian award Padma Shri.

Here is the reason why I have chosen to write you a letter. Murthy is one of the trustees of the Infosys Foundation which was founded in 1996. Through Foundation you built 2300 houses in flood-affected areas! Your great vision of the library for each school has resulted in the setting up of 70,000 libraries so far. I remember that when you appeared as a guest on KBC you highlighted the importance of toilets as the college in which you studied didn’t have any woman admitted before at that time. So you built 16000 public toilets and several hundreds of toilets in the city of Bangalore.

You are an amazing person who easily switches roles from storytelling to social service and administration. In one of your interviews, I read about how you miss being a teacher. I think how lucky must the students be who were your students back then. I wish if I could ever attend your speech. The only thought of it makes me so cheerful!

“Life is an exam where the syllabus is unknown and question papers are not set. Nor are there model answer papers.” Your quote inspired me a lot. It explained to me as well as the others the true meaning of life. Meeting you in person will be a wish in my bucket list!

Gautam Gandhi

AUTHOR
IT 3rd Sem

Kaushal Parmar

DESIGNER
IC 5th Sem
